elements.content: The use of 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpa) and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) as spacers has allowed us the rational design of new two-dimensional compounds having molecular formulas [M(μ-ox)(μ-bpa)] n (M(II) = Zn (1), Ni (2), Mn (3), Fe (4), or Cu (5); ox = oxalate dianion) and [M(μ-ox)(μ-bpe)] n (M(II) = Zn (6), Ni (7), Co (8), Fe (9), or Cu (10)). These compounds have been synthesized using diffusion and hydrothermal methods, and they have been characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis, and variable-temperature magnetic measurements. The X-ray structural analysis reveals that each metal atom is six-coordinated to four oxygen atoms belonging to two bridging oxalato ligands and two nitrogen atoms of two bidentate dipyridyl molecules to afford the expected 2D rectangular grid-type networks in which infinite [M(μ-ox)] n chains are cross-linked by the organic spacers. Each layer contains rectangles with dimensions of ca. 5 Å × 14 Å, the edges being defined by the oxalato and dipyridyl ligands. These rectangular cavities remain empty. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data show an overall antiferromagnetic behavior for all compounds except for Cu(II) polymers (5 and 10), which exhibit ferromagnetic interactions through the oxalato bridge in good accordance with their structural parameters.

These compounds have been synthesized using diffusion and hydrothermal methods, and they have been characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis, and variable-temperature magnetic measurements. Each layer contains rectangles with dimensions of ca. 5 Å × 14 Å, the edges being defined by the oxalato and dipyridyl ligands. These rectangular cavities remain empty. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data show an overall antiferromagnetic behavior for all compounds except for Cu(II) polymers (5 and 10), which exhibit ferromagnetic interactions through the oxalato bridge in good accordance with their structural parameters.

elements.content: A family of 2D rectangular grid-type compounds has been designed through the covalent connection of inorganic polymeric 1D metal−oxalato frameworks by bis(4-pyridyl) organic groups. The magnetic behavior of compounds has been analyzed on the basis of their structural characteristics.

The magnetic behavior of compounds has been analyzed on the basis of their structural characteristics.

elements.content: The design and exploration of new synthetic strategies to obtain novel metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has drawn an ever-increasing level of attention not only because of the fascinating structural diversities and novel topologies of this kind of compounds but also for their useful properties and promising applications as functional materials. A reasonable synthetic approach to build new coordination polymers with tailored-made architectures and specific chemical and physical properties consists of connecting transition metal ions through multidentate ligands containing N- or O-donor atoms or both to form multidimensional structures whose topologies can be controlled by a careful choice of the coordination nature of the metal nodes and the structural features of the organic linkers. For instance, rigid spacers may allow a controllable growth of the crystal structure, but in contrast, the adequate selection of flexible ligands increases the coordination versatility and could provide the formation of stable open frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and exploration of new synthetic strategies to obtain novel metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has drawn an ever-increasing level of attention not only because of the fascinating structural diversities and novel topologies of this kind of compounds but also for their useful properties and promising applications as functional materials. A reasonable synthetic approach to build new coordination polymers with tailored-made architectures and specific chemical and physical properties consists of connecting transition metal ions through multidentate ligands containing N- or O-donor atoms or both to form multidimensional structures whose topologies can be controlled by a careful choice of the coordination nature of the metal nodes and the structural features of the organic linkers. For instance, rigid spacers may allow a controllable growth of the crystal structure, but in contrast, the adequate selection of flexible ligands increases the coordination versatility and could provide the formation of stable open frameworks.

elements.content: In this respect, the oxalato ligand (dianion of oxalic acid, hereafter abbreviated ox) has appeared as a fruitful tecton for the design of a great diversity of homo- and hetero-transition metal compounds, which have played a key role in the theoretical and experimental development of areas such as inorganic crystal engineering and molecule-based magnetism. The main reasons for the extensive use of this old but evergreen ligand are (a) its remarkable ability to mediate electronic effects between metal centers affording compounds with a wide range of magnetic properties and (b) the prevalence of its rigid bis-chelating bridging mode providing some degree of predictability with regard to the structural characteristics of the resulting metal−oxalato networks. The topology and dimensionality of polymeric networks based on the oxalato-bridged ligand essentially depend on the shape of the templating counterions or on the features of the auxiliary organic ligands used to complete the metal coordination sphere or both (Chart ). The formation of hexagonal 2D-[MIIMIII(ox)3]- (MII = V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, or Zn; MIII = V, Cr, or Fe) honeycomb anionic layers is induced by voluminous achiral cations, such as [XR4]+ (X = N or P; R = phenyl, n-propyl, n-butyl, or n-pentyl), decamethylferrocenium, and tetrathiafulvalene derivatives. The use of chiral tris-chelated transition metal diimine complexes [M(L)3] m + (L = 2,2‘-bipyridine or phenantroline; m = 2 or 3) favors the formation of helical 3D-[M2(ox)3] n - networks where cation and anion exhibit inverted chirality. Discrete oligonuclear species (0D) are obtained by using multidentate N- or O− donor ligands that block most of the coordination sites around the metal center precluding the formation of extended polymeric metal−oxalato systems of higher dimensionality.

elements.content:
Tailoring of Metal−Oxalato Frameworks by Using Different Organic Ligands or Templating Counterions a

a  [1] Monodentate N-containing rings; [2] achiral cations; [3] chiral tris-chelated diimine cationic complexes; [4] bidentate ligands such as 4,4‘-bipy, piperidine, bpe, and bpa; [5] multidentate blocking N- or O-donor ligands.

elements.content: Interestingly, in a series of previous papers and in the framework of our research program concerning the use of structure-directing N-containing ligands in the synthesis of oxalato network structures, we have set up standard synthesis methods (nature of reactants and synthetic conditions) to achieve a straightforward design of zigzag or linear 1D complexes of formula [M(μ-ox)(L) x ] n (M(II) = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, or Zn) where pyridyl moieties, triazole derivatives, or even nucleobases12 behave as monodentate terminal or axial ligands, which permits the polymerization process of the metal−oxalato framework.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, in a series of previous papers and in the framework of our research program concerning the use of structure-directing N-containing ligands in the synthesis of oxalato network structures, we have set up standard synthesis methods (nature of reactants and synthetic conditions) to achieve a straightforward design of zigzag or linear 1D complexes of formula [M(μ-ox)(L) x ] n  (M(II) = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, or Zn) where pyridyl moieties, triazole derivatives, or even nucleobases12 behave as monodentate terminal or axial ligands, which permits the polymerization process of the metal-oxalato framework.

elements.content: By using similar synthetic routes now, we have succeeded in connecting 1D-[M(μ-ox)] n (M = MnII, FeII, CoII, NiII, CuII, or ZnII) frameworks through the neutral polyaromatic N-donor spacers 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpa) and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) to form 2D sheets with molecular formulas [M(μ-ox)(μ-bpa)] n (M(II) = Zn (1), Ni (2), Mn (3), Fe (4), or Cu (5)) and [M(μ-ox)(μ-bpe)] n (M(II) = Zn (6), Ni (7), Co (8), Fe (9), or Cu (10)). We report herein the synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal behavior of this new family of complexes. The magnetic properties of the compounds are also investigated, and the magneto-structural correlations are discussed in detail. These compounds are examples of crystal engineering, because we have shown how these organic spacers can be used to link metal−oxalato frameworks affording rectangular grid-type 2D architectures, as previously thought. Tailored derivatives of 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bipy) ligands with various spacers between the bipyridine functions have proven to be excellent cross-linked agents to increase the dimensionality of metal−organic frameworks affording double helices, two-dimensional grids, and covalent three-dimensional architectures with interesting properties such as porosity and zeolitic and spin-transition behavior.

We report herein the synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal behavior of this new family of complexes. The magnetic properties of the compounds are also investigated, and the magneto-structural correlations are discussed in detail. These compounds are examples of crystal engineering, because we have shown how these organic spacers can be used to link  metal-oxalato frameworks affording rectangular grid-type 2D architectures, as previously thought. Tailored derivatives of 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bipy) ligands with various spacers between the bipyridine functions have proven to be excellent cross-linked agents to increase the dimensionality of metal-organic frameworks affording double helices, two-dimensional grids, and covalent three-dimensional architectures with interesting properties such as porosity and zeolitic and spin-transition behavior.

elements.content:
Syntheses. Standard literature procedures were used to prepare the starting materials K2[Cu(ox)2]·2H2O and [Zn(ox)·2H2O] n .

[Zn( μ-ox)( μ -bpa)] n (1) and [Cu( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (5). Colorless prismatic crystals of 1 were grown in a test tube (1.5 cm × 15.0 cm) by the slow diffusion of a methanol solution of bpa (0.074 g, 0.4 mmol, 15 mL) into an aqueous solution (30 mL) containing [Zn(ox)·2H2O] n (0.038 g, 0.2 mmol) and K2ox·H2O (0.184 g, 1.0 mmol). To avoid the initial mixing of both solutions, a water layer (5 mL) was carefully placed between them. Light blue prismatic single crystals of 5 were obtained by the same procedure as that used for 1, but using K2[Cu(ox)2]·2H2O (0.071 g, 0.2 mmol) and K2ox·H2O (0.110 g, 0.6 mmol) with the same solution volume. After 2 months, suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were collected, washed with cold water and diethyl ether, and dried in air. Yield:  90%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12N2O4Zn:  C, 49.80; H, 3.58; N, 8.30; Zn, 19.37. Found:  C, 49.83; H, 3.57; N, 8.26; Zn, 19.33%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12CuN2O4:  C, 50.07; H, 3.60; N, 8.34; Cu, 18.92. Found:  C, 50.10; H, 3.65; N, 8.41; Cu, 19.00%.

elements.content: [Ni( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (2) and [Fe( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (4). Compounds 2 and 4 were prepared hydrothermally by reacting NiSO4·6H2O (0.222 g, 1.0 mmol) or FeCl2·4H2O (0.199 g, 1.0 mmol) with H2ox·2H2O (0.126 g, 1.0 mmol) and bpa (0.184 g, 1.0 mmol) in the presence of 6 mL of water. The reactions were carried out in a 23 mL digestion bomb for 144 h at 170 °C before cooling to room temperature at 10 °C/min. The final compounds were isolated as a blue polycrystalline sample (2) and red prismatic crystals (4) in an almost quantitative yield. They were washed with cold water and diethyl ether and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C14H12NiN2O4:  C, 50.81; H, 3.65; N, 8.46; Ni, 17.73. Found:  C, 50.90; H, 3.58; N, 8.52; Ni, 17.72%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12FeN2O4:  C, 51.25; H, 3.69; N, 8.54; Fe, 17.02. Found:  C, 51.12; H, 3.62; N, 8.61; Fe, 17.00%.

elements.content: [Mn( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (3). elements.content: [Zn( μ -ox)(μ-bpe)] n (6), [Ni( μ -ox)( μ -bpe)] n (7), [Co( μ -ox)( μ -bpe)] n (8), and [Fe( μ -ox)( μ -bpe)] n (9). These compounds were prepared hydrothermally by reacting ZnNO3·6H2O, NiSO4·6H2O, CoSO4·7H2O, or FeSO4·7H2O with H2ox·H2O and bpe in the molar ratio 1:1:2 in the presence of 8 mL of water for 6 days at 170 °C. elements.content: Physical Measurements. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 microanalytical analyzer. Metal content was determined by absorption spectrometry. The purity and homogeneity of the polycrystalline samples used for physical measurements were checked by IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and X-ray powder diffraction methods. The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a FTIR Mattson 1000 spectrometer in the 4000−400 cm-1 spectral region. Magnetic measurements were performed on polycrystalline samples of the complexes taken from the same uniform batches used for the structural determinations with a Quantum Design SQUID susceptometer covering the temperature range 5.0−300 K at a magnetic field of 1000 G. Thermal analyses (TG/DTA) were performed on a TA Instruments SDT 2960 thermal analyzer in a synthetic air atmosphere (79% N2/21% O2) with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1.

elements.content: X-ray Structural Studies. Single-crystal X-ray data of 1, 3−6, and 8 − 10 were collected at 293(2) K on an Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). All structures were solved by direct methods using the SIR92 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 including all reflections (SHELXL97). All calculations were performed using the WINGX crystallographic software package. Details of the structure determination and refinement of the compounds are summarized in Tables and . Bis-pyridyl ligands are disordered in two symmetry-related positions, and they were isotropically refined with restraints (SADI, EADP, and FLAT) and atomic occupancies of 50%.

Bis-pyridyl ligands are disordered in two symmetry-related positions, and they were isotropically refined with restraints (SADI, EADP, and FLAT) and atomic occupancies of 50%.

The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of nickel(II) compounds were collected on a Phillips X'PERT powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) over the range 10° < 2θ < 55° with a step size of 0.02° for 2 and 8° < 2θ < 60° with 0.03° of step size for 7 and an acquisition time of 15 s per step at 293 K. Indexation of the diffraction profiles was made by means of the FULLPROF program (pattern-matching analysis) on the basis of the space group and the cell parameters found for the compounds 4 and 8. The atomic coordinates of these compounds could not be refined due to the structural disorder shown in this family of compounds and the great number of parameters. The final unit-cell parameters are a = 9.638 Å, b = 13.601 Å, c = 10.510 Å, and β = 106.82° for 2 and a = 5.316 Å, b = 10.196 Å, and c = 13.548 Å for 7 (the final Rietveld plots are shown in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Syntheses. Hydrothermal and diffusion methods were employed for the synthesis of the compounds herein reported. In a first approach, we tried to obtain single crystals of the compounds by means of soft techniques, such as slow evaporation and diffusion methods, but some of them were obtained as polycrystalline samples due to their high insolubility. The hydrothermal method has proved to be an effective and powerful tool in the self-assembly of high-dimensional metal−organic coordination polymers, even though its reaction mechanism is not clear. As known, many transition metal carboxylato compounds with different additional ligands have been successfully prepared under autogenous pressure. The modified properties of water under these conditions minimize the solubility problems, and a wide range of organic and inorganic precursors may be used. It is well-known that at these conditions the metastable kinetic phases are more probably isolated rather than the thermodynamic ones. However, the great number of parameters that influence the hydrothermal synthesis (time, temperature, pH, reagents, stoichiometry) hinder the prediction of the reaction products. The experimental data provided by previous works about carboxylato-containing compounds and the knowledge of the coordination properties of the ligands and metals have allowed us to obtain the expected two-dimensional rectangular grid-type crystal structures employing diffusion methods and also hydrothermal synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses. Hydrothermal and diffusion methods were employed for the synthesis of the compounds herein reported. In  a first approach, we tried to obtain single crystals of the compounds by means of soft techniques, such as slow evaporation and diffusion methods, but some of them were obtained as polycrystalline samples due to their high insolubility. The hydrothermal method has proved to be an effective and powerful tool in the self-assembly of high-dimensional metal-organic coordination polymers, even though its reaction mechanism is not clear. As known, many transition metal carboxylato compounds with different additional ligands have been successfully prepared under autogenous pressure. The modified properties of water under these conditions minimize the solubility problems, and a wide range of organic and inorganic precursors may be used. It is well-known that at these conditions the metastable kinetic phases are more probably isolated rather than the thermodynamic ones. However, the great number of parameters that influence the hydrothermal synthesis (time, temperature, pH, reagents, stoichiometry) hinder the prediction of the reaction products. The experimental data provided by previous works about carboxylato-containing compounds and the knowledge of the coordination properties of the ligands and metals have allowed us to obtain the expected two-dimensional rectangular grid-type crystal structures employing diffusion methods and also hydrothermal synthesis.

elements.content: IR Spectroscopy. The IR spectra of the compounds are very similar showing the characteristic absorption bands of the bis-bidentate oxalato-bridging ligand:  1610−1625 cm-1 (νas  O - C - O), 1305−1315, 1350−1365 (νs  O - C - O), and 795−805 (δO - C - O). The peaks at 540 and 490 cm-1 (for compounds 1 − 5) and at 550 and 480−495 cm-1 (6 − 10) are assigned to νM - O and νM - N. The bands between 3100 and 2800 cm-1 and 1675−1400 cm-1 are attributable to the C−H, Car−Car, and CarN stretching frequencies of the aromatic group. In addition, the peaks at 1225 (m), 1210 (m), 1070 (m), and 830 (s) cm-1 can be assigned to the C−H in-plane or out-of-plane bend, ring breathing, and ring deformation absorptions of the organic ligands.

elements.content: Structural Description. X-ray diffraction analysis of compounds 1 − 5 shows that they are isomorphous and crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group (No. 15), whereas complexes 6 − 10 belong to the orthorhombic space group Immm (No. 71). Each metal atom has a distorted octahedral MO4N2 donor set, formed by four oxygen atoms from two bis-bidentate oxalato-bridging ligands and two trans-located nitrogen atoms from two bis(4-pyridyl) ligands (Figure ). In this way, the oxalato bridges sequentially connect metal centers to form an extended corrugated (1 − 5) or linear (6 − 10) 1D polymeric chain with a dihedral angle between two adjacent oxalato ligands of 30° and 0° for bpa and bpe complexes, respectively. The metal−oxalato neutral chains are further linked by bidentate dipyridyl spacers to result in a neutral two-dimensional [M(μ-ox)(μ-L)] n (L = bpa and bpe) structure with a (4,4) topology as shown in Figure .

elements.content: Selected bond lengths and angles for the coordination polyhedron and the M···M separation across the bridging ligands are listed in Tables and . The metal ions of compounds 1 − 5 are located on a crystallographic 2-fold axis parallel to the M−bpa chains, which implies the disorder of the bpa atoms over two positions. Dipyridyl bridging ligands of compounds 6 − 10 are also disordered over two positions related by a symmetry plane. Compound 5 exhibits the expected tetragonal Jahn−Teller elongation of the copper(II) octahedron with two axial bond distances (Cu−O, 2.314(3) Å) substantially longer than equatorial ones (<2.05 Å). The difference of the Cu−O bond lengths (0.34 Å) involving the bis-bidentate oxalato ligand is similar to those observed in other six-coordinated copper(II) complexes based on asymmetrically coordinated oxalato bridges. The atoms involved in the four short bonds [O(1), O(1)b, N(11), and N(22)c] define the equatorial plane of the coordination polyhedron, which forms a dihedral angle of 80° with the oxalato-bridging plane. Although the same Jahn−Teller effect is expected for compound 10, the values of bond distances represent an environment around the Cu(II) that is more akin to a rare example of “2 + 4” tetragonal compressed coordination. In almost all cases of observed Jahn−Teller “compression” examined in detail to date in the literature, the apparent compression is due to static/dynamic disorder of two of the possible axial elongations. All our attempts to solve and refine the crystal structure of 10 considering disorder or a lower symmetry were unsuccessful. However, the values of the anisotropic displacement parameters of several atoms of the metal−oxalato framework along the b axis seem to indicate the existence of elongation accompanied by crystallographic disorder. The remaining compounds exhibit a slightly tetragonally elongated octahedral metal(II) coordination with metal−ligand bond distances for the trans-coordinated dipyridyl spacers longer than those involving the oxalato ligand. The M−O and M−N bond distances are in the expected range in comparison with other polynuclear oxalato and dipyridyl complexes registered in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, January 2006 release).

In each sheet, every four metal nodes are linked by two oxalato ligands and two organic spacers to afford an oblong ring of approximate dimensions 5 Å × 14 Å. The dimensions of the cavity are not large enough to accommodate another net, and it allows an understanding of why the compounds do not exhibit an interpenetrating structure. The sheets are parallel stacked along the crystallographic a-axis (1 − 5) and b-axis (6 − 10) and cross-linked by means of weak C−H···Oox hydrogen bonding interactions between neighboring layers, which sustains the overall 3D supramolecular architecture. Despite the resemblances of both covalent 2D frameworks, the overall crystal packing of compounds exhibits significant differences basically owing to the conformational flexibility and rigidity of bis(4-pyridyl) bridging ligands.

Despite the resemblances of both covalent 2D frameworks, the overall crystal packing of compounds exhibits significant differences basically owing to the conformational flexibility and rigidity of bis(4-pyridyl) bridging ligands.

elements.content: The bidentate 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane is a quite flexible spacer that can adopt anti and gauche conformations. However, the first one seems to be the most stable, as can been deduced from the relative fewer number of crystalline materials with gauche conformation reported in the literature. Moreover, a great number of crystal structures containing the anti-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane show a twisting angle between the two pyridine rings equal or very near to zero (<10°), but compounds with torsion angles of up to 90° are not rare. The bpa spacer in compounds 1 − 5 presents anti conformation, and the two aromatic rings are perpendicularly twisted with dihedral angles ranging from 48.6° (for 3) to 55.3° (for 5). One of the rings is only tilted by around 28° with respect to the sheet plane, whereas the other ring is twisted by ca. 80°. This arrangement partially inserts the bpa rings into the rectangular void and precludes the usual incorporation of solvation molecules. The adjacent sheets are displaced by b/2 along the organic spacer to avoid steric hindrances, and this allows pyridinic hydrogen atoms to establish weak C−H···O hydrogen bonds with the oxalato oxygen atoms of neighboring layers as acceptors, affording an interlayer space of ca. 4.6 Å.

elements.content: As far as the bidentate 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene ligand is concerned, it is a more rigid spacer and exhibits an almost coplanar conformation in the great majority of its complexes, although rare examples have been reported with dihedral angles up to 74°. Indeed, the bpe bridges of the compounds 6 − 10 show the usual coplanar conformation, and they are exactly perpendicular to the 2D-grid sheet. This less puckered form produces a longer interlaminar space (ca. 5.1 Å) than that observed for the bpa complexes and generates a 0.5(a + c) offset stacking of the consecutive layers with an ABAB sequence, in such way that the metal nodes of the adjacent B sheets are placed below and above the centers of the rectangular voids of the A sheet (Figure ). The offset stacking precludes the porosity of the structure but moves the ethylene hydrogen atoms closer to the oxalato-bridging ligands of the neighboring sheets to connect them, together with pyridinic hydrogen atoms, by means of weak C−H···O contacts.

elements.content: It is necessary to note that the structural dimensions of this kind of 2D rectangular grid-type compound could be tailored by the right choice of the interlinking organic groups. Indeed, the crystal packing of the bpe compounds is close to that found in the analogous complexes where metal−oxalato chains are connected by the 4,4‘-bipy ligand. However, in the 4,4‘-bipy complexes, the sheets are separated by 5.5 Å, a longer value than those measured for the bpe compounds. This structural difference is because of the distance between the C−H hydrogen-bond donors. The twisting of the pyridine ring in the bpa ligand allows a closer approach of the sheets, and the separation values between the hydrogen atoms involved in the weak C−H···O interactions are shorter for the bpe than those found for the 4,4‘-bipy (Figure ). Moreover, the intermetallic distance spaced by the 4,4‘-bipy ligand is 11.4 Å, which is evidently shorter than the values found in the bpa and bpe compounds.

elements.content: Thermal Analysis. The robustness of the overall supramolecular three-dimensional architecture of the compounds has been confirmed by their thermal behaviors, which have been deduced from the TG and DTA curves in synthetic air (see Supporting Information). Copper(II) compounds show lower degradation temperature retaining their stability up to 220 (5) and 230 °C (10). After this temperature, they undergo successive decomposition processes to yield Cu(II) oxide as final black powdery product above 280 °C for 5 and 345 °C for 10. The crystal cohesiveness of the remaining structures is more robust. The thermal degradation processes start in the range 270−360 °C to produce MO (1, 2, 6, and 7) or M2O3 (3, 4, 8, and 9) as final products above 450 °C. The thermal curves of the compounds show that the decomposition process takes place in only one step except for zinc(II) complexes (1 and 6), which exhibit two exothermic processes (DTA peaks at 390 and 415 °C for 1 and 405 and 420 °C for 6).
elements.clean_text: Thermal Analysis. The robustness of the overall supramolecular three-dimensional architecture of the compounds has been confirmed by their thermal behaviors, which have been deduced from the TG and DTA curves in synthetic air (see Supporting Information). Copper(II) compounds show lower degradation temperature retaining their stability up to 220 (5) and 230 °C (10). After this temperature, they undergo successive decomposition processes to yield Cu(II) oxide as final black powdery product above 280 °C for 5 and 345 °C for 10. The crystal cohesiveness of the remaining structures is more robust. The thermal degradation processes start in the range 270-360 °C to produce MO (1, 2, 6, and 7) or M2O3 (3, 4, 8, and 9) as final products above 450 °C. The thermal curves of the compounds show that the decomposition process takes place in only one step except for zinc(II) complexes (1 and 6), which  exhibit two exothermic processes (DTA peaks at 390 and 415 °C for 1 and 405 and 420 °C for 6).

elements.content: Magnetic Properties. Although the covalent structure of the compounds is two-dimensional, from a magnetic point of view, the systems can be considered as one-dimensional owing to the long M···M distances (>13 Å) along the organic linkers, for which we can assume a negligible magnetic exchange through the bpa and bpe ligands and analyze their magnetic properties based on chain models.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic Properties. Although the covalent structure of the compounds is two-dimensional, from a magnetic point of view, the systems can be considered as one-dimensional owing to the long M⋅⋅⋅M distances (>13 Å) along the organic linkers, for which we can assume a negligible magnetic exchange through the bpa and bpe ligands and analyze their magnetic properties based on chain models.

elements.content: Figure shows the thermal dependence of the χ M (molar magnetic susceptibility per metal atom) and the χ M T product of the nickel(II) complexes (2 and 7). Both χ M curves exhibit a maximum around 50 (2) and 55 K (7) and then decrease sharply, which is characteristic of an antiferromagnetic coupling. The fitting of the magnetic data over the whole temperature range by means of numerical expressions proposed for S = 1 chains with uniform antiferromagnetic interactions does not match the experimental data in the vicinity of the maximum and overestimates the values of the magnetic susceptibility at lower temperatures. If the model is applied in the high-temperature region (T > 35 K) good fits are obtained:  J = −27.1 cm-1, g = 2.23, and R = 9.5 × 10-4 for 2 and J = −30.0 cm-1, g = 2.25, and R = 9.1 × 10-4 for 7, where R is the agreement factor defined as R = ∑ i [(χ M)obs(i) − (χ M)calc(i)]2/∑ i [(χ M)obs(i)]2. The disagreement of the model at low temperatures is probably due to the existence of antiferromagnetic intermolecular interactions, zero-field splitting, or a one-dimensional Haldane gap. The inclusion of a θ parameter to take into account the intermolecular interactions does not improve the fit. Haldane predicted that integer-spin chains should have an energy gap between the singlet ground state and the first excited triplet states. Therefore, the magnetic susceptibility increases exponentially from 0 as T is raised. The lower temperature region (T < 35 K) could be successfully fitted with Haldane gap, by eq 1, where E g denotes the energy gap. The best fits obtained are E g = 7.32 and 10.29 cm-1 for 2 and 7, respectively, which are in good agreement with the correlation E g ≈ 0.41|J| calculated by Monte Carlo methods.

elements.content: Previous magnetostructural studies of binuclear oxalato-bridged Ni(II) complexes have revealed that the magnitude of the exchange coupling constant is strongly dependent on the nature of the donor atoms in the peripheral ligands. The lowest values of J were reported for the dimer (H3dien)2[Ni2(μ-ox)(ox)4] (dien = diethylentriamine) (J = −22.8 cm-1)8 and the one-dimensional chain [Ni(μ-ox)(H2O)2] n (J = −22.0 cm-1) with NiO6 chromophores, while binuclear systems in which the nickel(II) atoms are placed in a O2N4 environment show the highest values (J ranges from −32 to −40 cm-1). The observed J values for compounds 2 and 7 are in the range (between −23 and −31 cm-1) reported for one-dimensional complexes with a O4N2 donor set. The replacement of oxygen by nitrogen atoms in the nickel(II) coordination polyhedron is accompanied by an increase in the antiferromagnetic coupling due to the smaller electronegativity of the donor atom, which interacts more strongly with the nickel d orbitals and induces a strong hybridization toward the bridging ligand, thus favoring a larger bridge orbital overlap.

The observed J values for compounds 2 and 7 are in the range (between -23 and -31 cm-1) reported for one-dimensional complexes with a O4N2 donor set.     The replacement of oxygen by nitrogen atoms in the nickel(II) coordination polyhedron is accompanied by an increase in the antiferromagnetic coupling due to the smaller electronegativity of the donor atom, which interacts more strongly with the nickel d orbitals and induces a strong hybridization toward the bridging ligand, thus favoring a larger bridge orbital overlap.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compound 3 in the form χ M and χ M T vs T are represented in Figure . The room-temperature value for χ M T (4.45 cm3 mol-1 K) is very similar to the spin-only value (4.38 cm3 mol-1 K considering g = 2.00) expected for a high-spin d5 Mn(II) ion. It remains almost constant up to 100 K, and then it decreases rapidly upon further cooling. The χ M curve increases when the compound is cooled until a maximum is reached at 12.5 K, and then it decreases very quickly. This behavior is indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling between the manganese(II) centers through the oxalato-bridging ligands. The experimental data have been successfully fitted by means of a S = 5/2 Fisher antiferromagnetic chain model derived through the Hamiltonian H = − J∑S i S i +1. The best-fit parameters are J = −2.2 cm-1, g = 2.01, and R = 1.3 × 10-4 (solid lines in Figure ).

elements.content: The magnitude of the antiferromagnetic interaction previously reported for oxalato-bridged manganese(II) complexes ranges from −0.9 cm-1 for the 1D-trans-[Mn(μ-ox)(H2O)2] n compound with a MnO6 chromophore to −3.0 cm-1 for the dimer [Mn2(μ-ox)(bpppa)2](ClO4)2 (bpppa = N-benzyl-N-((6-pivaloylamido-2-pyridyl)methyl)-N-((2-pyridylmethyl)amine) with a MnO2N4 coordination polyhedron. The J value of compound 3 is similar to those found for the compounds [Cr2Mn2(ox)5(phen)2(2,2‘-bipy)2(H2O)2]·6H2O (J = −2.2 cm-1) and 1D-[Mn(μ-ox)(4atr)2] n (J = −1.7 cm-1, 4atr = 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole)10 with the same O4N2 donor set. These data seem to indicate a similar relationship between the electronegativity of the donor atoms and the observed antiferromagnetic coupling to that above-described for the oxalato-bridged nickel(II) complexes.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of complexes 4 and 9 is quite similar, so the thermal dependence of χ M T and χ M of only compound 9 is shown in Figure . The χ M T value at room temperature is 3.2 cm3 mol-1 K, which is somewhat above that calculated for a magnetically noninteracting spin quintet through the spin-only formula (χ M T = 3.0 cm3 mol-1 K with g = 2.0). These values remain almost constant up to 80 K and then exhibit a continuous decrease upon cooling to practically vanish at 5 K. The magnetic susceptibility curves exhibit maximum at 31 (4) and 34 K (9), revealing that a significant antiferromagnetic interaction between the high-spin iron(II) ions occurs. Our attempts to reproduce theoretically the susceptibility magnetic data by using the classical spin Heisenberg chain model39 (with S = 2) gave the best-fit parameters J = −6.1 cm-1, g = 2.30 for 4 and J = −6.5 cm-1, g = 2.38 for 9, but the computed χ M curves do not match the experimental data well in the vicinity of the maximum of susceptibility, with the position of the theoretical maximum being shifted toward lower temperature with respect to the experimental one, indicating that the J values of the magnetic interactions obtained are underestimated. The consideration of an additional θ parameter accounting for the interchain interactions did not improve significantly the quality of the fit. Most likely, the mismatch between the calculated curve and the experimental data may originate from the fact that the model does not take into account the orbital contribution, which is significant for the octahedral high-spin iron(II) ion (5T2g ground state). Anyway, the J values are physically reasonable, and they are quite close to that found in the structurally charaterized iron(II) chains [Fe(μ-ox)(H2O)2] n (J = −8.8 cm-1, Fe···Fe 5.570 Å) and [Fe(μ-ox)(dpa)] n (J = −8.0 cm-1, Fe···Fe 5.545 Å) with a nearly identical separation across the bridging oxalato group. Antiferromagnetic couplings with J values ranging from −5 to −9 cm-1 have been reported for other oxalato-bridged Fe(II) compounds.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compound 8 in the form χ M vs T are represented in the Figure . The χ M curve exhibits a maximum at 35 K with a value of 3.0 × 10-2 cm3 mol-1, and then decreases very quickly. The χ M T value at room temperature (2.80 cm3 mol-1 K) is significantly greater than the spin-only value for a high-spin Co(II) center (1.875 cm3 mol-1 K for S = 3/2 and g = 2.0), but it agrees with the values observed for octahedral cobalt(II) complexes with a significant first-order orbital contribution to the magnetic moment. The inverse magnetic susceptibility follows a Curie−Weiss law above 130 K with C = 3.23 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = −41.2 K.

elements.content: A detailed quantitative analysis of the susceptibility data for cobalt(II) complexes is complicated by the fact that the orbital moment, spin−orbit coupling, distortions from regular stereochemistry, electron delocalization, and crystal field mixing of excited states into the ground state affect the magnetic properties (in addition to a possible magnetic interaction), and noninteracting Co(II) systems may show strong deviations from the simple Curie behavior. In a first approach, we have attempted to fit the experimental susceptibility in the entire temperature range using the classical spin Heisenberg model39 for a one-dimensional chain of S Co = 3/2. A reasonable agreement was obtained with the parameters J = −14.2 cm-1 and g = 2.73 at T > 60 K, but the results are not very satisfactory in the low-temperature region because the model does not take into account the effects of the spin−orbit coupling for octahedral Co(II) complexes (4T1g ground state).

In a first approach, we have attempted to fit the experimental susceptibility in the entire temperature range using the classical spin Heisenberg model39 for a one-dimensional chain of S Co = 3/2. A reasonable agreement was obtained with the parameters J = -14.2 cm-1 and g = 2.73 at T > 60 K, but the results are not very satisfactory in the low-temperature region because the model does not take into account the effects of the spin-orbit coupling for octahedral Co(II) complexes (4T1g ground state).

elements.content: Previous magnetic reports showed that some 1D systems of cobalt(II) are associated with anisotropic Ising systems with an effective spin S‘ = 1/2, and they can be fitted at low-temperature range (T < 40 K) where only the ground Kramer's doublet is thermally populated. At higher temperatures, a crossover to the Heisenberg-type behavior is expected. The best fit (shown in the inset of Figure ) gave the parameters g x = 3.44, g z = 7.21, and J = −16.0 cm-1, which are quite close to those obtained for the one-dimensional [Co(μ-ox)(H2O)2] n (J = −13.4 cm-1) and {[Co(μ-ox)(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (J = −14.2 cm-1)47 compounds through the same magnetic model.

At higher temperatures, a crossover to the Heisenberg-type behavior is expected. The best fit (shown in the inset of Figure ) gave the parameters g  x  = 3.44, g  z  = 7.21, and J = -16.0 cm-1, which are quite close to those obtained for the one-dimensional [Co(μ-ox)(H2O)2] n  (J = -13.4 cm-1) and {[Co(μ-ox)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (J = -14.2 cm-1)47 compounds through the same magnetic model.

elements.content: More recently, Rueff et al. have proposed a phenomenological approach for some low-dimensional Co(II) systems that allows one to have an estimate of the strength of the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions by means of eq 2 in which A + B equals the Curie constant and E 1 and E 2 represent the “activation energies” corresponding to spin−orbit coupling and the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction. The A + B value of 3.35 cm3 mol-1 K obtained with the Rueff procedure perfectly agrees with those given in the literature for the Curie constant (C = 2.8−3.5 cm3 mol-1 K). E 1/k B, the effect of spin−orbit coupling and site distortion, is 54.5 K, according to the values reported for several 1D and 2D Co(II) complexes (ca. +50 K). Regarding the value found for the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction (E 2/k B = 10.8 K, J = −15.0 cm-1), it is of the same magnitude as those obtained in the Heisenberg and Ising chain models, and it is comparable to those found for other oxalato-bridged cobalt(II) complexes in which exchange couplings of up to −25 cm-1 have been reported.

The χ M T value increases continuously from 0.43 cm3 mol-1 K at room temperature to 0.68 cm3 mol-1 K at 5 K. The shape of the magnetization curve at 5.0 K (inset of Figure ), and the values of the saturation magnetization are as those expected for the case of ferromagnetic coupling between local spin doublets. elements.content: For oxalato-bridged Cu(II) complexes, it has been found that the value and type of the magnetic coupling is essentially governed by the magnitude of the overlap between the symmetry-adapted highest occupied molecular orbitals of the oxalato ligand and the metal-centered magnetic orbitals (mainly, a d x 2 - y 2 type orbital in tetragonally elongated octahedral geometries). The J values range from −400 cm-1 when the four oxalato oxygen atoms are coordinated with short bond distances to each copper(II) center in such a way that is coplanar with the singly occupied molecular orbitals (SOMOs) of the copper atoms (coplanar topology)9,11,12,55,56 to weak antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic (accidental orthogonality) coupling when the oxalato behaves as an asymmetric bis-bidentate bridging ligand and the two metal-centered magnetic orbitals are parallel to each other and perpendicular to the oxalato (perpendicular topology, inset of Figure ). It has also been observed that the value of the bond angle C−O−Cu involving the apical oxalato-oxygen atom (β) is the main structural factor that governs the nature of the magnetic interaction for the perpendicular topology. Compounds with β ≤ 109.5° show ferromagnetic interactions, whereas for β > 109.5°, the magnetic coupling between copper(II) ions is antiferromagnetic. The weak ferromagnetic coupling observed for compound 5 is in good agreement with its perpendicular topology and the observed β angle of 106.9°, and it is similar to those found for the 1D [Cu(μ-ox)(2ampy)2] n (2ampy = 2-aminopyridine, J = +2.0 cm-1, β = 107.8°), [Cu(μ-ox)(4atr)2] n (J = +2.2 cm-1, β = 108.0°), and [Cu(μ-ox)(2,2‘-bipy)2]·2H2O} n (J = +2.4 cm-1, β = 108.4°). The above-described, apparent Jahn−Teller compression of the coordination polyhedron found in compound 10 precludes an appropriated discussion of its magneto-structural correlations.

elements.content: It has been shown that the oxalato dianion in combination with organic spacers such as bis(4-pyridyl) derivatives is an excellent ligand for constructing two-dimensional metal−organic framework structures with transition metal ions. Moreover, the supramolecular architectures of the reported complexes (and the 4,4‘-bipy analogous) is fine-tuned by the features of the organic spacers. Compounds behave as monodimensional magnetic systems in which the sign and size of the magnetic couplings through the bis-bidentate oxalato-bridging ligand are in good accordance with the structural parameters, and they are in the range found for previously reported 1D polymeric μ-oxalatometal(II) complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

It has been shown that the oxalato dianion in combination with organic spacers such as bis(4-pyridyl) derivatives is an excellent ligand for constructing two-dimensional metal-organic framework structures with transition metal ions. Moreover, the supramolecular architectures of the reported complexes (and the 4,4‘-bipy analogous) is fine-tuned by the features of the organic spacers. Compounds behave as monodimensional magnetic systems in which the sign and size of the magnetic couplings through the bis-bidentate oxalato-bridging ligand are in good accordance with the structural parameters, and they are in the range found for previously reported 1D polymeric μ-oxalatometal(II) complexes.

cln_elements.content:
Syntheses. Standard literature procedures were used to prepare the starting materials K2[Cu(ox)2]·2H2O and [Zn(ox)·2H2O] n .

[Zn( μ-ox)( μ -bpa)] n (1) and [Cu( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (5). Colorless prismatic crystals of 1 were grown in a test tube (1.5 cm × 15.0 cm) by the slow diffusion of a methanol solution of bpa (0.074 g, 0.4 mmol, 15 mL) into an aqueous solution (30 mL) containing [Zn(ox)·2H2O] n (0.038 g, 0.2 mmol) and K2ox·H2O (0.184 g, 1.0 mmol). To avoid the initial mixing of both solutions, a water layer (5 mL) was carefully placed between them. Light blue prismatic single crystals of 5 were obtained by the same procedure as that used for 1, but using K2[Cu(ox)2]·2H2O (0.071 g, 0.2 mmol) and K2ox·H2O (0.110 g, 0.6 mmol) with the same solution volume. After 2 months, suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were collected, washed with cold water and diethyl ether, and dried in air. Yield:  90%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12N2O4Zn:  C, 49.80; H, 3.58; N, 8.30; Zn, 19.37. Found:  C, 49.83; H, 3.57; N, 8.26; Zn, 19.33%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12CuN2O4:  C, 50.07; H, 3.60; N, 8.34; Cu, 18.92. Found:  C, 50.10; H, 3.65; N, 8.41; Cu, 19.00%.

[Ni( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (2) and [Fe( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (4). Compounds 2 and 4 were prepared hydrothermally by reacting NiSO4·6H2O (0.222 g, 1.0 mmol) or FeCl2·4H2O (0.199 g, 1.0 mmol) with H2ox·2H2O (0.126 g, 1.0 mmol) and bpa (0.184 g, 1.0 mmol) in the presence of 6 mL of water. The reactions were carried out in a 23 mL digestion bomb for 144 h at 170 °C before cooling to room temperature at 10 °C/min. The final compounds were isolated as a blue polycrystalline sample (2) and red prismatic crystals (4) in an almost quantitative yield. They were washed with cold water and diethyl ether and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C14H12NiN2O4:  C, 50.81; H, 3.65; N, 8.46; Ni, 17.73. Found:  C, 50.90; H, 3.58; N, 8.52; Ni, 17.72%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12FeN2O4:  C, 51.25; H, 3.69; N, 8.54; Fe, 17.02. Found:  C, 51.12; H, 3.62; N, 8.61; Fe, 17.00%.

[Mn( μ -ox)( μ -bpa)] n (3). Colorless prismatic single crystals of 3 were grown by layering a methanol solution of bpa (0.074 g, 0.4 mmol) and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.050 g, 0.2 mmol) onto an aqueous solution of H2ox·2H2O (0.050 g, 0.4 mmol) following the same procedure as that for compounds 1 and 5. After 4 weeks, colorless crystals were isolated on standing at room temperature. They were washed with cold water and diethyl ether and dried in air. Yield:  80%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12MnN2O4:  C, 51.39; H, 3.70; N, 8.56; Mn, 16.79. Found:  C, 51.48; H, 3.62; N, 8.99; Mn, 16.82%.

[Cu( μ -ox)( μ -bpe)] n (10). This compound was prepared by following an analogous procedure to that for 5 but using bpe (0.146 g, 0.8 mmol). Crystal growth was observed after 2 weeks, and the blue prismatic single crystals were washed with cold water and diethyl ether and dried in air. Yield:  80%. Anal. Calcd for C14H10CuN2O4:  C, 50.38; H, 3.02; N, 8.39; Cu, 19.04. Found:  C, 50.48; H, 3.06; N, 8.46; Cu, 19.22%.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal Analysis. The robustness of the overall supramolecular three-dimensional architecture of the compounds has been confirmed by their thermal behaviors, which have been deduced from the TG and DTA curves in synthetic air (see Supporting Information). Copper(II) compounds show lower degradation temperature retaining their stability up to 220 (5) and 230 °C (10). After this temperature, they undergo successive decomposition processes to yield Cu(II) oxide as final black powdery product above 280 °C for 5 and 345 °C for 10. The crystal cohesiveness of the remaining structures is more robust. The thermal degradation processes start in the range 270−360 °C to produce MO (1, 2, 6, and 7) or M2O3 (3, 4, 8, and 9) as final products above 450 °C. The thermal curves of the compounds show that the decomposition process takes place in only one step except for zinc(II) complexes (1 and 6), which exhibit two exothermic processes (DTA peaks at 390 and 415 °C for 1 and 405 and 420 °C for 6).

The magnetic properties of compound 8 in the form χ M vs T are represented in the Figure . The χ M curve exhibits a maximum at 35 K with a value of 3.0 × 10-2 cm3 mol-1, and then decreases very quickly. The χ M T value at room temperature (2.80 cm3 mol-1 K) is significantly greater than the spin-only value for a high-spin Co(II) center (1.875 cm3 mol-1 K for S = 3/2 and g = 2.0), but it agrees with the values observed for octahedral cobalt(II) complexes with a significant first-order orbital contribution to the magnetic moment. The inverse magnetic susceptibility follows a Curie−Weiss law above 130 K with C = 3.23 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = −41.2 K.

The magnetic data for 5 and 10 are practically identical, so the thermal dependence of χ M T for only compound 5 is shown in Figure . The χ M T value increases continuously from 0.43 cm3 mol-1 K at room temperature to 0.68 cm3 mol-1 K at 5 K. The shape of the magnetization curve at 5.0 K (inset of Figure ), and the values of the saturation magnetization are as those expected for the case of ferromagnetic coupling between local spin doublets. The fitting of the experimental data by means of the numerical expression proposed for a ferromagnetic uniform copper(II) chain led to J = +2.50 cm-1 and g = 2.11 for 5 and J = +2.00 cm-1and g = 2.15 for 10.
